metadata.case_name: Appellant (Composite Insurer) v. Life Insurance Corporation of India

facts.text: The appellant used to carry on both life and other kinds of insurance business and was a composite insurer under the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956.

The respondent Life Insurance Corporation was created by the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 on September 1, 1956 (appointed day), and under s.7 all rights appertaining to the life insurance business (controlled business) of insurers vested in the Corporation.

Under Income-tax Act, 1922 assessment orders for 1955-56 and 1956-57, appellant entitled to refunds due to tax deducted at source under s.18(3) and amounts added to dividends under s.16(2) exceeding tax payable.

For assessment year 1955-56 (previous year 1954), credit given for taxes earlier paid: Rs. 48,271.56 (life department), Rs. 3,245.25 (general department). Assessed on total income Rs. 1,26,524/- after profit Rs.1,50,191/- (life) and loss Rs.23,667/- (general). Refund Rs.12,867.58.
Assessment for 1955-56 made on September 29, 1956, revised May 21, 1957.

For assessment year 1956-57 (previous year 1955), credit for taxes earlier paid: Rs.48,271.56 (life), Rs.3,196.25 (general). Profit Rs.1,51,835/- (life), loss Rs.2,06,083/- (general), overall loss, full refund of credited taxes.
Assessments made after appointed day (September 1, 1956). Taxes credited were deductions under s.18(3) and additions under s.16(2) of Income-tax Act.
LIC claimed Rs.9,622.43 out of 1955-56 refund and Rs.48,271.56 out of 1956-57 refund under s.7 LIC Act.
Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur (Case No.24/XII/1959) decided in favour of LIC on August 3, 1959.
Appellant maintained separate life insurance fund under s.10(2) Insurance Act, 1938; shares/securities appertained to life fund or general business.
Refund amount already paid by Government; appellant received its share; LIC received balance on October 15, 1959 per court order September 21, 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether the right to income-tax refunds for assessment years 1955-56 and 1956-57 existed on September 1, 1956 and appertained to the controlled business (life insurance business) of the appellant so as to vest in the LIC under s.7 of LIC Act, 1956.
In what proportion should the refunds be distributed between life insurance business and general business.

petitioner_arguments.text: The right to refund did not appertain to any particular business but belonged to the assessee as a whole under s.48 Income-tax Act; not transferable under s.7 LIC Act to life business specifically.
Deductions from life business income ceased to be assets of that business; refund right not appertaining to life business.
Life business would unfairly benefit from general business losses.

respondent_arguments.text: Right to refund appertained to controlled business (life insurance) as taxes deducted from its income; vested in LIC under s.7(1) LIC Act.

court_reasoning.text: Right to refund existed on September 1, 1956 as liability to tax existed per Finance Acts and s.3 Income-tax Act; assessment merely particularises amount.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right ascertainable on April 1, 1955 and 1956 when income computable and rates known.

court_reasoning.text: Right appertained to life insurance business per Insurance Act, 1938 (s.10,11,13; Schedules) requiring separate accounts/funds for life business; income from life assets (shares/securities) appertains to life business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Refund is return of excess tax from life business income; retains character as life business asset.

court_reasoning.text: Deductions were provisional payments; excess never ceased to be asset of life business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to decide if s.16(2) additions are deductions.

court_reasoning.text: No advantage from losses; right arises from overall position but appertains to source (life business).
For 1956-57: Full refund distribution per department - appellant Rs.3,196.25 (general), LIC Rs.48,271.56 (life).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Each gets from its own assets.

court_reasoning.text: For 1955-56: General dept. gets full Rs.3,245.25 (no tax liability due to loss); balance to LIC as from life dept.

holdings.text: Right to refund of excess tax deducted from or treated as paid on income of life insurance business assets appertains to controlled business and vests in LIC under s.7 LIC Act.
Refunds apportioned: 1956-57 - LIC Rs.48,271.56, appellant Rs.3,196.25; 1955-56 - LIC Rs.9,622.43 (balance after appellant's Rs.3,245.25).

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Liability to tax exists throughout year per s.3 Income-tax Act and Finance Act rates.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Vests assets including rights appertaining to controlled (life insurance) business in LIC on appointed day.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs tax deductions at source on securities/dividends, grossing up dividends, refunds of excess tax.

statutes_cited.name: Insurance Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires separate life insurance fund/accounts; assets/income from life business kept distinct.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Tribunal order dismissed in principle; court agrees Tribunal view correct but specifies exact apportionment of refunds between appellant (general business share) and LIC (life business share). Declares LIC entitled to balance already paid to it.
outcome.relief_granted: LIC entitled to Rs.48,271.56 (1956-57 life) and balance Rs.9,622.43 (1955-56 life); appellant retains general shares.

key_quotes.text: "When s. 7 mentions a right appertaining to his controlled business it obviously contemplates a right existing in relation to that business, for the business not being a legal person, could not own any right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'right appertaining to controlled business' under s.7 LIC Act.

key_quotes.text: "The assessment only particularised the amounts it did not create the right, for the right came into existence as soon as according to the relative Finance Act it became ascertainable that the tax deducted at source... had exceeded the tax payable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes existence of refund right pre-vesting.

key_quotes.text: "Upon its return it could not change its previous nature it would still remain the income of the life insurance business. A right to the return of this income would therefore also be a right appertaining to the life insurance business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds refund retains character of source income.
